nodes.title: Pannello di controllo: tieni traccia di tutto in un unico posto
nodes.subtitle: Il Pannello di controllo di MetaMask Portfolio ti offre un quadro chiaro di tutti i tuoi conti in un'unica finestra.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
In MetaMask Portfolio, il Pannello di Controllo ti d√† un'idea dei tuoi wallet: i tuoi token, i tuoi NFT e le tue transazioni aggregate su pi√π conti e reti. Per conoscere il valore totale del tuo wallet vai su portfolio.metamask.io per collegare il tuo wallet MetaMask e i conti associati. Puoi anche importare qualsiasi altro wallet incollando il suo indirizzo pubblico.


Criptovalute e NFT


La vista completa del Pannello di controllo ti permette di tenere traccia delle tue diverse criptovalute, che si tratti di stablecoin, memecoin, token nativi della blockchain e NFT.

Invece di andare in un mercato NFT per vedere la tua collezione, puoi semplicemente passare alla scheda NFT per apprezzare e visualizzare gli NFT artistici, i POAP e altro ancora. Il Pannello di controllo ha come impostazione predefinita una versione pulita, che filtra gli NFT nascosti e sospetti in modo che tu non debba visualizzare lo spam. Inoltre, separa gli NFT di tua propriet√† dagli NFT di altri account che guardi. Non sentirti in colpa per aver curiosato nelle collezioni altrui, alla fine sono tutte concatenate.

Aggregazione multi-catena


Puoi selezionare fino a sette reti per visualizzare tutti i tuoi asset, invece di passare alle singole reti per visualizzarle una alla volta.

MetaMask Portfolio attualmente supporta sette reti:

  1. Ethereum
  2. Optimism
  3. Arbitrum
  4. BNB Chain
  5. Polygon
  6. Avalanche
  7. Fantom

Basta selezionare tutte le reti di cui vuoi visualizzare i saldi ed il pannello di controllo inserir√† cos√¨ gli asset nella tua finestra.

Attivit√† concatenata


Stai cercando di ricordare le cose che stavi facendo mesi fa? Lo capiamo. Per questo motivo il monitoraggio delle transazioni √® molto utile, in modo che tu possa ottenere queste informazioni passando alla scheda "Transazioni" all'interno del Pannello di controllo senza mai lasciare MetaMask Portfolio.

MetaMask Portfolio ha come impostazione predefinita una visuale pulita delle tue transazioni, in modo da darti un'idea pi√π precisa dei token e degli NFT con cui hai interagito. Questo aiuta a eliminare lo spam, ma puoi sempre scegliere di mostrare le transazioni non verificate. Potresti trovare dei token interessanti che ti vengono consegnati a caso!
(Ma fai attenzione quando interagisci con loro.)

All'interno della scheda delle transazioni, puoi visualizzare la tua attivit√† sulla catena di Ethereum, Polygon e Avalanche, mentre altre saranno presto aggiunte.

Puoi anche scaricare un file con tutte le tue transazioni per organizzarle e conservarle pi√π facilmente. Potrebbe anche semplificare il periodo del pagamento delle tasse‚Ä¶

Una finestra


L'interfaccia intuitiva del Pannello di controllo ti permette di gestire e tenere traccia dei tuoi token in modo semplice. Grazie all'aggregazione di tutte le tue cripto, NFT e transazioni su pi√π conti e reti, puoi avere una visione approfondita dell'attivit√† del tuo wallet in un'unica finestra, senza doverti destreggiare tra pi√π dapp.

Pronto ad approfondire l'argomento? Scopri di pi√π su metamask.io/portfolio/.

nodes.title: MetaMask Extension‚Äôs updated UX elevates network, dapp, and account selection
nodes.subtitle: Learn about the wallet‚Äôs new look and how it provides a simpler web3 experience.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
We‚Äôre excited to unveil some changes to the MetaMask wallet extension with v10.33 that make it simpler, cleaner, and more intuitive to use than ever before.

You'll notice a crisper layout when you first open the fox head on your browser.

The two top rows which previously displayed wallet address, connection status, network selection, and account selection have now been condensed into a single top row, minimizing visual noise and giving you everything you need at a quick glance.

In addition, we've made site connections more obvious on the top right (check image below) so you can easily see and manage the dapps your MetaMask wallet is interacting with. This helps with granting permissions and knowing what you‚Äôre connecting to.

To avoid confusing elements‚Äîyes, we heard you and went to work‚Äîwe separated the account selection from the global menu navigation and placed the account avatar right by the account name so you always have a clear visual association with your identity. This seemingly minor change has profound implications by increasing your awareness and confidence when interacting with dapps.

Finally, the network selector moved to the top left within the header and each network is now associated with its respective token. This unique pairing helps distinguish different chains from each other and promotes user safety.

At MetaMask, we encourage safe and secure web3 habits. We hope this new user experience makes your web3 journey more simple and enjoyable. This UX was inspired by user feedback, and we encourage you to keep telling us what you think! We take note. Remember, MetaMask Portfolio spun out from popular community request. üòâ

Till next time‚Ä¶

Happy browsing! üåêü¶ä

nodes.title: MetaMask and PayPal, all you need to know about buying ETH
nodes.subtitle: MetaMask is the first web3 wallet to allow U.S. users to buy ETH easily with PayPal.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
MetaMask‚Äôs buy crypto solution within the wallet makes purchasing Ethereum (ETH) and other currencies easy. Adding to the list of payment options, PayPal is available as a payment method for our users across the U.S. (excl. Hawaii).

MetaMask is the first web3 wallet to enable users to buy ETH using PayPal, a leader in the digital payment space. In addition to purchasing ETH directly, the integration also supports the transfer of ETH from PayPal to MetaMask, aiding in more self-custody adoption.



What is PayPal?


In addition to being one of the most popular digital payments providers, PayPal also offers cryptocurrency services on its platform. With this new integration, users will be able to use their PayPal balance, linked bank account, or debit card to add ETH to their MetaMask wallet directly.

How do I get started?


PayPal‚Äôs U.S. users can now buy ETH in a handful of clicks. You will be prompted to sign up with PayPal if you don‚Äôt currently have an account with them.

To add ETH to your MetaMask wallet with PayPal in the U.S.:

  1. Login into the MetaMask browser extension, mobile app, or MetaMask Portfolio. (If you haven‚Äôt downloaded MetaMask yet, start here).
  2. Click or tap ‚ÄúBUY‚Äù to get started.
  3. Select country (US only) and state (PayPal‚Äôs crypto services are available in 49 states; not in Hawaii).
  4. Choose ‚ÄúPayPal‚Äù as your payment method.
  5. Select ETH and enter the amount you want to buy (This is the only cryptocurrency currently available for purchase through PayPal on MetaMask).
  6. Sign in to your PayPal account.
  7. Select payment option of choice: PayPal balance, eligible bank, or debit card.
  8. Review purchase and click ‚ÄúConfirm‚Äù.
  9. Success!!! ü¶ä Onto core web3 activities ü¶ä

It‚Äôs that simple. PayPal‚Äôs easy crypto purchasing solution allows you to enjoy your funds quickly, on the go. Ready to dive in?

nodes.title: Account Abstraction: Past, Present, Future
nodes.subtitle: Learn about account abstraction in Ethereum‚Äîwhat it means and why it matters.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Even with a bear market raging on, few people doubt crypto is here to stay‚Äîwallets like MetaMask already boast millions of users, for example. But, still, the question remains: ‚ÄúHow do we go about bringing the next billion users to web3?‚Äù

Depending on who you ask, answers to the question will vary. But everyone agrees on some points‚Äîparticularly the need to improve the experience of users interacting with blockchain applications. Without making web3 more user-friendly, people have little incentive to switch from the web2 apps they use every day.

‚ÄúAccount abstraction‚Äù is a proposal seeking to improve user interactions with Ethereum‚Äîone that‚Äôs increasingly the subject of many discussions in the crypto community. You may, however, be thinking: ‚ÄúWhat exactly is account abstraction and why should I care about it?‚Äù

This article is designed to help you make sense of account abstraction by putting its past, present, and future into context. We‚Äôll be answering every question you may have about the topic‚Äîspecifically, the who, what, why, how, and when of account abstraction.

A quick summary of key talking points:

  • Programmable, self-custodial accounts (‚Äúsmart accounts‚Äù) can reduce the friction of onboarding new users to the web3 ecosystem. However, limitations imposed by Ethereum‚Äôs design prevent broad adoption and use of smart accounts.
  • Account abstraction introduces significant changes that pave the way for wide adoption of trustless, censorship-resistant smart accounts. Different approaches to implementing account abstraction are being considered‚Äîeach featuring unique benefits and tradeoffs.
  • MetaMask is supporting adoption of account abstraction through its permissionless innovation platform: MetaMask Snaps. With MetaMask Snaps, developers can extend MetaMask to bring the benefits of account abstraction to crypto users around the world.

What is account abstraction?


Like any other new concept in web3, account abstraction can be hard to define. Nevertheless, we can better understand it by first unpacking the various terms relevant to the discussion of account abstraction in Ethereum:

  1. Abstraction (n): A (fairly complicated) term in computer science that roughly means hiding information about a system or application so it can be used with less knowledge of the processes running in the background. Also defined as ‚Äúthe process of hiding the complexity of a system by providing an interface that eases its manipulation.‚Äù

  2. Account (n): A user's representation on the blockchain that can send or receive transactions and interact with other on-chain accounts. Ethereum has two types of accounts: Externally Owned Accounts (EOAs) and contract accounts (aka ‚Äúsmart contracts‚Äù).

2a. Externally Owned Accounts (EOA): Ethereum accounts generated using wallet software (like MetaMask) and managed by a cryptographic pair of public and private keys. An EOA is ‚Äúactive‚Äù (it can initiate transactions and pay gas fees for EVM execution). However, it is limited to executing basic operations‚Äîlike sending Ether or interacting with contracts.

2b. Contract accounts: Ethereum accounts deployed as a smart contract and controlled by logic written in code (instead of a private key). A contract account is ‚Äúpassive‚Äù: it can only send transactions in response to a transaction from an EOA and cannot pay gas fees. It is, however, programmable and can execute arbitrary logic depending on code stored at the address.

  1. Wallet (n): An interface for managing the funds in your Ethereum account‚Äîhow a wallet operates depends on what type of account it is linked with. An EOA-based wallet like MetaMask requires a private key to authorize transactions. Meanwhile, a smart contract wallet is linked to a contract account and can use arbitrary logic to authorize a transactions (eg. using a multisignature scheme).

With these definitions out of the way, we can now define account abstraction.

Defining account abstraction

Account abstraction is a proposal to increase flexibility in the management and behavior of Ethereum accounts. We achieve this by introducing account contracts: special-purpose smart contracts that define and manage a user‚Äôs Ethereum account (now called a smart account).

With account abstraction, you can enjoy programmable access to funds by using a smart contract wallet instead of relying solely on private keys for security. This is possible because your smart account can have custom rules for spending coins and transferring assets.

So, how does ‚Äúabstraction‚Äù fit into all of this?

From a network-level perspective, ‚Äúaccount abstraction‚Äù means the details of account types are invisible to the Ethereum protocol. Every account (including self-custodial accounts) is simply a smart contract, and users are free to determine how individual accounts are managed and operated.

From a user-level perspective, ‚Äúaccount abstraction‚Äù means certain technical details about interacting with Ethereum accounts are concealed behind higher-level interfaces. This improves wallet designs and significantly reduces the complexity of using web3 applications.

This clarification is necessary because confusion around account abstraction comes from not knowing (a) what is being abstracted and (b) where the abstraction occurs. Accounts aren‚Äôt necessarily abstracted from users (even if they are abstracted from the protocol). You still have a wallet address to receive funds and a signing key to ensure only you can spend those funds.

From your perspective, account abstraction is more like using a smart account that abstracts some details about interacting with the blockchain. For context, this is what interacting with a dapp looks like from the perspective of a first-time user:

With account abstraction, wallet developers can create systems that handle these processes in the background and simplify the experience of using web3 (TL;DR: wallets become ‚Äúinvisible‚Äù). Some use cases (which we‚Äôll expand on later) include: eliminating the need for you to store seed phrases/private keys, pay gas for transactions, or even set up an on-chain account by yourself.

The benefits of account abstraction


As mentioned previously, account abstraction removes most of the friction associated with using web3 wallets and interacting with dapps. This brings web3 closer to the ideal of web2 where all users‚Äîboth novice and experienced‚Äîcan benefit from the same degree of flexibility, security, and ease of use.

In particular, account abstraction has huge implications for the future of self-custody. With the features provided by account contracts, using a web3 wallet will feel like using a bank account or application without having to trust the bank.

In subsequent sections, we‚Äôll touch on the different dimensions of account abstraction and discuss how they improve the experience of using Ethereum. Specifically, we‚Äôll talk about signature abstraction, fee abstraction, and nonce abstraction.

Signature abstraction


Today, transactions from your EOA must have a signature generated by the account‚Äôs private key using the Elliptic curve digital signature algorithm (ECDSA) to be valid. This gives most EOAs a simple security model: funds are safe if private keys remain in the user‚Äôs possession. But it also has several limitations:

  1. EOAs are notoriously difficult to secure, particularly as malicious actors are always evolving new ways of compromising private keys. At MetaMask, we‚Äôve seen firsthand the challenges that phishing, social engineering, spoofing, malware injection, and similar attacks pose to user security in web3.

  2. Self-custody may feel like an extreme sport. Unlike your regular bank account, you cannot ‚Äúrecover‚Äù an EOA wallet if the seed phrase/private key is lost. This creates a challenge for new users who must grapple with the implications of completely losing assets held in Ethereum accounts without any recourse.

Signature abstraction solves these problems by removing ECDSA signatures as the default authorization mechanism for non-custodial accounts. Rather, users are permitted to define custom rules for authorizing wallets to initiate transactions. Or, said another way, you can decide what it means for a transaction to be valid.

Implementing signature abstraction opens up possibilities for more advanced authorization schemes. This way, using your web3 wallet will feel similar, if not better than, a web2 banking application. Here are some use cases:

  1. Transaction limits: A wallet linked to your smart account can reject a transaction (or ask for additional authorization) if the value exceeds a preset limit. Sounds familiar? It should‚Äîbanks do it already to protect your accounts and credit cards against fraud, unauthorized usage, and other reasons related to security.

  2. Multi-party approvals: You could delegate partial control of your account to trusted parties aka ‚Äúguardians‚Äù. Guardians can be friends, family members, service providers, or even a separate device that you own (eg. a hardware wallet). Thus you can enable web2-style multi-factor authentication (MFA) for your wallet by requiring guardian approval for transactions that withdraw funds from your smart account.

  1. Key rotation and revocation: With smart accounts, you can generate a new signing key if the previous key was lost or stolen. For additional security, you can have guardians freeze your account during the recovery process and demand approval for key rotation/revocation flows (ie. social recovery). This is similar to how you can freeze your credit card if it‚Äôs misplaced/stolen without losing access to your bank account

  2. Trusted sessions: Do you dislike having to approve every action when interacting with a dapp in your browser? Great! You can create special ‚Äúsession keys‚Äù with your smart account for dapps to automatically sign transactions for a specific period. This means you can interact with dapps‚Äîplaying a blockchain game, say‚Äîwithout getting pestered with wallet pop-ups.

At a high level, session keys are based on a smart contract that controls interactions between your account and a dapp. You always have control of session keys and can regulate the dapp‚Äôs signing authority, such as how much it can deduct from your balance or what functions it can call.

  1. Automatic payments: Similar to the idea of session keys, you can approve service providers to ‚Äúpull‚Äù funds from your smart account (subject to predefined rules). This makes it possible to set up recurring payments and subscriptions with your web3 wallet. Can you imagine paying for a Netflix subscription or utility bill using your Ethereum account?

Fee abstraction


Currently, every Ethereum transaction must have a ‚Äúgas fee‚Äù denoting how much the sending EOA is willing to pay for execution. Gas fees are denominated in Ether, Ethereum‚Äôs native token. This creates problems, especially for new users who now need to source for ETH before sending their transaction.

Account abstraction doesn‚Äôt eliminate the need to pay gas fees, but it abstracts away details of how and when users choose to pay for gas (fee abstraction). For example, account abstraction enables ‚Äúsponsored transactions‚Äù where another account covers the cost of gas for a user‚Äôs transaction. Some benefits of sponsored transactions:

  1. Non-ETH gas payments: Have you ever wished you could pay for transaction fees with ERC-20 tokens in your wallet? With sponsored transactions, you can get a relayer with ETH to front the cost for your transactions and pay them back in another token like DAI or USDC.

  1. Gasless transactions: Dapp developers can sponsor transactions and minimize onboarding friction for new Ethereum users. You could essentially be using web3 apps without knowing anything about ‚Äúgas‚Äù and enjoy the same one-click experience that web2 apps provide.

  1. Social logins: A dapp might deploy a contract wallet on your behalf, solving the pain point of setting up a wallet before sending on-chain transactions. The great part? Wallets can use authentication infrastructure (eg. Web3Auth and WebAuthn) to enable users to create web3 accounts with existing credentials like an email address or Facebook/Twitter account.

Nonce abstraction


Smart accounts on Ethereum have another special feature: transaction batching. With batched transactions, you can combine multiple operations into a single on-chain transaction and reduce the cost and complexity of interacting with dapps. Here‚Äôs why transaction batching is important:

Your EOA stores a value known as a ‚Äúnonce‚Äù that shows how many transactions you‚Äôve sent (think of it like a transaction counter). A new transaction must strictly increase the nonce by 1 to be valid‚Äîa rule that prevents someone else from ‚Äúreplaying‚Äù the same transaction to steal your funds (yup, it can happen).

But there‚Äôs a catch. Nonces force you to process transactions in first-in-first-out (FIFO) style. Imagine you have two transactions (A and B) with nonce of 0 and 1, respectively. Here, you‚Äôd send transaction A and wait for a confirmation (of its execution) before sending B.

Sending B while A is still pending would simply have the former rejected since the nonce would be higher than the prescribed range (EOA‚Äôs current nonce + 1). In fact, this is a big reason you have ‚Äústuck transactions" when using a wallet.

Nonce abstraction allows you to create custom replay protection mechanisms (instead of the Ethereum protocol enforcing strict ordering on transactions). For example, you can have a nonce scheme that permits processing multiple transactions in parallel. This would solve the problem of clogged/stuck transactions and significantly improve interactions with dapps.

That said, nonce abstraction is difficult to implement in practice and can potentially break certain invariants critical to security and UX, such as transaction hash uniqueness). This is where transaction batching comes into the picture:

Since smart accounts can process multiple transactions at once, the need for complex nonce abstraction schemes largely disappears. Going back to the previous example, we can imagine transaction A and B are merely parts of a single hypothetical operation like swapping assets on Uniswap:

  • Transaction A: Approve the Uniswap contract to access your tokens
  • Transaction B: Complete the token swap

With transaction batching, you can combine the approve-and-swap workflow into one transaction. The result: lower gas fees and reduced wait-times when using dapps. Cool, eh?

The ‚Äúhow‚Äù of account abstraction


At this point, you already know account abstraction allows us to add custom functionality and authorization policies to user accounts. But we really haven‚Äôt talked about how any of that is possible. This section discusses different approaches to implementing abstraction on Ethereum (if that doesn‚Äôt sound too appealing, feel free to skip to the next section).

There are two generally accepted ways of achieving account abstraction: (a) letting EOAs execute EVM code and (b) allowing smart contracts to initiate transactions. Hence, you‚Äôll find that many account abstraction proposals either want EOAs to behave as smart contracts or contract accounts to act as EOAs.

This naturally brings up some questions:

  • ‚ÄúHow exactly are these approaches different?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWhy does it matter which approach we adopt?"

Account abstraction: Approach #1 (Upgrading EOAs to execute code)


By giving EOAs the ability to execute code, we can add complex functionality to user-controlled accounts. This supercharges EOAs and transforms them into smart accounts, setting the stage for native account abstraction. Importantly, this approach allows you to enjoy the benefits of a programmable wallet without incurring the cost of deploying a new contract account.

Some approaches to upgrading EOAs to contract accounts involve treating the data payload of EOA transactions as EVM bytecode. Others involve delegating control of an EOA to a special account contract that makes transactions on the EOA‚Äôs behalf. In the latter case, the same account contract can be reused by different EOAs, reducing the need to have different contract wallet implementations.

Below is an infographic showing different account abstraction proposals in the ‚Äúmake EOAs programmable‚Äù camp, including their key features and status of implementation:

Account abstraction: Approach #2 (Upgrading smart contracts)


With this approach, we upgrade contract accounts so they can approve transactions and pay gas fees (just like EOAs). This provides another route to achieving account abstraction by introducing ‚Äúsupercharged contracts‚Äù that can act as EOAs (ie. account contracts). Plus, it solves a pressing problem in Ethereum: lack of support for contract wallets at the protocol level.

You see‚Äîsome smart contract wallets already exist today and provide many benefits of account abstraction. But using these wallets can be incredibly difficult because Ethereum treats smart contracts as ‚Äúsecond-class citizens‚Äù and requires all transactions to start from an EOA.

This limitation also means smart contract wallets lack the trustlessness and self-custodial nature of EOA wallets like MetaMask. For context, let‚Äôs consider the flow of creating and using a smart contract wallet:

  • Deploy a new contract account
  • Send transactions to call functions on your wallet contract

The problem is already obvious: you now need to manage two wallets. Why? An EOA (pre-funded with ETH) needs to cover the costs of deploying the wallet and calling necessary functions afterwards.

Enter relayers: EOAs that can pay for your wallet‚Äôs transactions in exchange for a fee. Smart contract wallet providers will often run relayers to subsidize transactions for users. That is, the relayer pays ETH from its wallet to cover your transaction fees and recoups the costs by charging you elsewhere‚Äîperhaps in fiat or some other token.

This system works fine in most cases: you can create and use a contract wallet without worrying too much about the intricacies of paying for gas. However, it also requires trusting the relayer not to censor or tamper with your transactions.

But this is crypto, and we like trustless systems.

By letting contract accounts approve transactions and pay gas fees, account abstraction makes the process of creating and using a smart contract wallet more trustless. To be specific, it allows anyone that runs a relayer to execute transactions on your behalf. You just need to sign a message approving the relayer to deduct funds from your wallet balance after executing the transaction:

Now the flow of using a smart contract wallet looks somewhat different:

  • Deploying a wallet contract? By using counterfactual deployment workflows, you can send funds to the contract account before deploying it and pay a relayer‚Äôs EOA for deployment costs from your wallet‚Äôs balance.
  • Interacting with a wallet contract? Sign a message off-chain and have a relayer make the call to your account contract. The message will include an instruction for the account contract to refund the relayer‚Äôs gas costs.

This idea of enabling trustless and censorship-resistant smart accounts underpins many account abstraction proposals in this category. For example, ERC-4337‚Äîthe most popular account abstraction proposal yet‚Äîdecentralizes relayers by introducing an alternate mempool where users can submit contract wallet transactions for processing.

In this case, relayers (called ‚Äúbundlers‚Äù) can compete to execute smart account transactions, reducing the risk of censorship or over-reliance on wallet providers. Below is an infographic showing different account abstraction proposals in the ‚Äúgive smart contracts EOA features‚Äù camp, including their key features, and status of implementation:

On the future of account abstraction


Years after Vitalik Buterin first introduced the concept, there‚Äôs still some disagreement about the best way to implement account abstraction. For example, implementing EIP-3074 and EIP-5003 would enable existing EOAs (including MetaMask users) to upgrade to smart accounts. But these proposals require a hard fork which, given the community‚Äôs focus on more pressing upgrades, seems infeasible for now.

In contrast, EIP-4337 has received broad support as it implements account abstraction without requiring large-scale changes to the Ethereum protocol. But for users currently using EOA-based wallets, it means having to move assets from an EOA to a newly deployed contract account‚Äîa potentially complex and costly process, given high gas fees on Ethereum today.

At MetaMask, we believe account abstraction is key to providing a seamless onboarding experience for new web3 users. We also know that EOAs cannot guarantee crypto‚Äôs adoption (‚ÄúThe next billion users won‚Äôt write 12 words on a paper,‚Äù as Ethereum Foundation researcher Yoav Weiss colorfully puts it.).

As such, we have begun thinking of ways to deliver the benefits of account abstraction without compromising on the MetaMask wallet users know and love. Part of this effort includes turning to MetaMask Snaps‚Äîthe permissionless innovation platform that allows developers to build custom features on top of existing MetaMask infrastructure.

Using Snaps, developers can extend the functionality of your MetaMask wallet to support different account abstraction use cases. From session keys to complete smart account integrations built with MetaMask‚Äîall built with Snaps‚Äîwe have seen developers rise to the challenge of using MetaMask to democratize access to account abstraction for users.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt let perfect be the enemy of good.‚Äù ‚Äî Voltaire


The current account abstraction proposal‚Äîeven if slightly imperfect‚Äîis a giant step towards achieving trustless, censorship-resistant smart accounts on Ethereum and deserves enough support. To quote one of our own, Taylor Monahan, ‚ÄúA shipped half-solution is still better than an unshipped perfect solution.‚Äù

Which is why our next article on the topic of account abstraction will take the form of a deep dive into the details of ERC-4337. Importantly, we‚Äôll discuss how web3 developers can start building the future of account abstraction and onboard the next billion users‚Äîone line of code at a time‚Äîwith MetaMask.

Stay tuned!

Special thanks to Patrick McCorry, Simon Brown, Mirko Garozzo, Christian Montoya, Oliver Renwick, and Megan Dias for feedback on earlier drafts of this article. My appreciation also goes out to Clarissa Watson and Francesco Andreoli who provided guidance and support in the early stages of the project.
